14:48 ACTUALLY! Canadian here: bagged milk has a MUCH lower environmental impact than cartons or jugs. Now, I totally hear you on the video's main issue of restricted zoning. It's ridiculous, and it needs to change. Thank you for highlighting it. However, over and over again you roll shots of these "walkable" neighborhoods, and the central feature is a train track and people on bikes. Even in walkable cities, people can't always walk. If I need to pop 2 miles across my cute little walkable city, I'd much rather get there in 6 minutes on a train than 45 minutes on foot. The same is true for suburbs! Lightrails are the closest thing we have to traveling via tubes. Buses are complicated, as they don't tend to run in a straight line like trains, and you there's no clear visual indication of what overall direction any given bus is gonna go. You have to consult the schedules/routes. Trains are simple: "the tracks go that way, we're going that way."   I think it's very possible to build a functional, convenient suburb. All US cities have to do is reach out and take it: 1. Build your favorite flavor of urban sprawl 2. Identify direction of nearest civilization 3. Build light rail tracks along urban sprawl toward civiliation 4. The cost of annual rail passes is included in HOA fees. Your family members get their passes the day they move in.   That's the clear answer to me. This setup fits as perfectly into that nice-looking CO neighborhood at 15:17 as the barren wastes at 0:53. Make the train part of the neighborhood's identity. Advertise its usage heavily throughout the neighborhood. Create a rewards program: more rides, more points. Give away merch. Have a storefront along the tracks specifically dedicated to rider support. Have the track go directly through/into areas that cars can't go; of course I'd rather ride in on the train when it cuts straight through the heart of the shopping zone, whereas my car has to be parked at the very edge. Use bigass traincars absolutely filled with bike racks inside. Prioritize getting EV shops along the tracks. Build a culture of transit users. No matter what kind of zoning you may be able to get, it's equally useful. Light rail + personal electric vehicles are the future of transit. I say this from experience; I live in one of the most convenient suburbs in America where the light rail and ebikes/escooters are a VERY viable alternative to driving. They did the work and made it happen. It works. And we've got areas like that CO neighborhood all along the tracks, as well as miles and miles of traditional urban sprawl. Some of my ideas above are definitely beyond what they've been able to do here, but maybe someday. For now it's working, and it's giving people who don't drive, can't afford to drive, kids under 16, and people with disabilities the ability to get around, regardless of what kind of zoning they live in.

Unfortunately, the policies that supposedly "eliminated single family Zoning" haven't really done that. As someone in the middle of the search for a home in a supposedly progressive city in a progressive state, the only multi-family housing available is million-dollar waterfront condos or run-down complexes that call themselves apartments yet are somehow still Car-dependent and 60% parking lot. Looking at the Zoning codes for our city, pretty much everything is still single-family in practice, just with the option to add an ADU. This is true even in many blocks downtown. In short, more proactive policies are needed to force cities to abandon this kind of zoning where it makes sense to do so, because otherwise, the Karens and the NIMBYs will always win. Building regulations also need to be simplified, since "progressive" cities tend to have such onerous regulations that only luxury housing can make a profit. There also needs to be more centralized planning of transit, as our current transit planning process is too expensive and slow to keep up with growth (and no, biking won't solve that). In sum, while it's easy to say the big bogey man is R-1 zoning and that all we need to do is get rid of that, reality is much more complicated, and there isn't a single policy change that will end suburban sprawl.

If you've ever walked through a medieval town center in Germany, Switzerland, Italy, Poland, Czechia etc., you may recognize certain common features. The bags of milk come from when Canada switched to the metric system, but all milk jugs were in imperial measurements.  It was a quick fix until machinery was retooled to produce metric containers.  However I can tell you from living in Canada for a few years that the Milk Bags are pretty cool.  You buy a big bag subdivided into smaller bags, and throw what you don't need immediately into the freezer to keep longer.  You also buy a plastic pitcher designed specifically for the bags and cut off the corner of the bag to dispense.  It works better than you would think.  Here in Wisconsin you can buy bagged milk at places like Kwik Trip.

I have lived in the suburbs all of my life and there are a lot of problems created by simplistic zoning laws. Before modern zoning laws each suburban governmental unit had a downtown where all of the government offices and routine shopping stores were all withing walking distance. Folks not living within walking distance could drive into the downtown area and then walk to any place they had to go. The main street area was where your link to public transportation was. Also all of the retail stores and at least one or two floors above the shops for low cost housing that provided affordable housing for most of the people who worked at low paying jobs in the town. There was also on main street reasonable sized apartments houses, usually right near a bus stop. Modern zoning laws do not allow for large housing projects to contain convenience stores so that people don‚Äôt have to drive to buy daily necessities. Today in New Jersey builders can build as much housing as they want as long as a handful of units are ‚Äúaffordable‚Äù When I researched what the definition of affordable was it turned out to be 20% less than market price. So if the new units were selling for a million dollars, an ‚Äúaffordable‚Äù unit was $800,000.  The other issue is lack of public transportation. With today‚Äôs high cost of maintaining a private car the working poor have no way of getting to work. The labor shortage is not because people don‚Äôt want to work but because they can‚Äôt live with a commutable distance of where the jobs are.

No need for special designed extra containers and tools and prepping. And is it really so crucial to stock your fridge so full of stuff that your milk container needs to conform to everything else instead of taking up a few inches of space for he brief period it takes you to use up the milk? American person living in America (briefly?) but own a flat in a high rise in Europe. I'd love to see more urban housing, but there aren't zero problems with it in Europe either. For example, my flat is in a mostly glass building, and it gets like a greenhouse in even slightly warm weather, which is a huge problem. Glass buildings are also a LOT of energy and not climate-friendly material to create. If you have all (or mostly) glass buildings that are tall, you'll *need* them to have AC to be liveable, especially with hotter and hotter years. They also require expensive energy solutions and maintenance compared to houses. That doesn't mean they aren't worth building, but it's important to factor this in  when building high rises and weigh it up against building shorter buildings. I'd also like to see larger homes available and many more homes available, because when you have small homes and not enough homes, you end up with 1 and 2 bedroom flats near/in the city centre costing the equivalent of $1 million (and average wages 1/20th of this). A scary thought if this also spreads to America.

Unfortunately, in many cases rezoning of neighborhoods, although not expressly "about" taking away someone's detached-family house, becomes about that. You have older people who came up during the time when that was the ideal, worked all their lives, paid off their houses...and then are forced out by skyrocketing property taxes. Or shaded out by big buildings on either side of them, or look out to their once nice view of a lake and now see a huge, ugly apartment building that has monopolized the view for their tenants (all of whom pay premium prices for that view). Of course those single family homeowners will get old and eventually may become unable to live in those homes any longer, but they're just trying to enjoy what they worked all their lives for.  And let's not pretend that the most of those developers are in it to increase quality of life for anyone. In many cities, especially ones like Seattle with its housing shortage, they're doing it to make a quick buck. The people losing their neighborhood and often their homes, get accused of nimbyism and standing in the way of increased density. But why must the final conclusion be that the developer and the big money behind them should get the final say?  Of course there are good developments as well, and some are creating that combination of accessibility, density, shopping, third places and culture that makes a new development truly desirable. We need a lot more of that kind of development, and it's slowly starting to happen.  But when developers are building crappy plastic-looking 6-story buildings, and adding nothing in terms of shopping or other amenities but rather just cramming more people in to get more $$ from rents, it's not hard to understand why residents object.

Small land owners are deprived from development rights, they are not allowed to add any density on their lots even if they want, at the same time you propose new high rise construction which will add many new users to the infrastructure without paying a fair share. The land value and a property tax will go up, with no option to build more. Why should they support such construction?  Transferable Development Rights (TDR) could be a good solution for this problem. If there is a development potential in the neighborhood why should it be granted to any individual land owner - shouldn‚Äôt it belong to each landlord proportionally to property tax?  Want to oppose density - keep paying for excess of TDR. Willing to decrease tax burden - sell surplus of TDR to your neighbor who is willing to build more. New infrastructure may first go to the neighborhoods which are willing to utilize TDR this infrastructure creates.

Hey Rollie, good job making an engaging zoning video! I appreciate your concern for using correct terminology, but I'm here to go down a little tangent if you'll indulge me. Regarding the use of "culs-de-sac" as the plural of "cul-de-sac," I believe "cul-de-sacs" is more appropriate and I'll explain why. If you weren't already aware, the phrase originates from French, meaning "bottom of the bag." If we are talking about multiple roads, each of which is the "bottom of the bag," we would say they are the "bottomS of the bagS" not that they are the "bottomS of the bag" (note the capitalization of certain "s" for clarity).  A bag only as one bottom, therefore there must be multiple bags if multiple streets qualify as a bottom of a bag. Therefore, adding the "s" onto "sac" makes more sense than adding it to "cul." I can't wait for the replies telling me I'm wrong because I've over-thought this and loanwords don't have to follow logic.

0:13 It's actually not obvious that your friend John isn't blind.
I'm all for walkable communities if done correctly. My city tried to build a walkable community 5 story housing project where the ground floor would be shops and businesses and the other 4 floors would be low income housing. 3 yrs later and they have yet to attract even a single business to rent ground floor space. The other 4 floors have been filled with poor people which has led to a rise in crime...which is probably why no business wants to move in.   I disagree, however, that high density cities are better for the environment. This is propaganda pushed by those that benefit from agglomeration economies...mostly politicians and industrialists. Most studies that claim urban life is better measure residential energy use or personal vehicle ownership. While I won't dispute the findings, I will say that these aspects are only a small sliver of things one should consider. Cities have commercial and industrial energy consumption AND pollution that rural settings don't (which is why most studies only look at residential). And sure urban car ownership rates might be half as much as rural but those comparisons don't take into account the fleets of taxis, police cruises, fire trucks, cargo vans, and delivery trucks that aren't usually found in more rural settings.  And if we're talking "climate change" let's not ignore the fact that cities can actually change climates. The lack of green spaces combined with the common building materials used in most cities (asphalt, concrete, brick, stone, steel, etc) means cities retain heat and cause massive thermal updrafts which carry surface CO2 into the upper atmosphere where CO2 has the most impact on climate change.  But the real damage cities do has less to do with climate change and more to do with pollution in general. Single use packaging, trash, human waste, water pollution and air pollution are much more concentrated in urban environments. Even if you could somehow argue cities produce less refuse and pollution per capita, that refuse and pollution is still concentrated and not easily managed without severe impact to the environment.   Lastly, while zoning can definitely be improved, it's not like single family zoning is causing suburbs to be suburbs. Suburbs exist because people with means want the convenience of living near the city but don't want to put up with the crime and poor school systems. This will never change.

When you said "Belmar", I raised an eyebrow.  When  you brought up Villa Italia, I laughed, because I remember watching that that entire transformation, from Villa's grand opening, its heyday, it's decline, and the emergence of Belmar.  And it's not alone - if memory serves, there are only four actual "malls" left in the Metro area - Aurora, Southwest Plaza, Cherry Creek, and Park Meadows.  Many others died in much the same way as Villa Italia, and have been rebuilt in mixed zone fashion.  Heck, Villa/Belmar wasn't even the first - though Cinderella City had additional factors that led to its downfall - like subpar materials on the raised parking level that slowly eroded until the upper floor looked like something out of a nightmare - asphalt with waves like an urban ocean.   I confess, I shed a few tears when it was torn down, because I have memories beyond the "'80s Mall Rat" thing - a weekly trip there for lunch with my grandmother after her hair appointment, a seasonal job, and so on.  But since it _had_ been such a fixture in my early years, I could also see that it was time... and for the most part, I do like the changes that came with it, even if it is not as robust as Belmar.   Not fond of all the acres of parking that somehow seemed to increase with the strip malls that took over, and the apartments that went up were expensive _before_ the housing crunch, but there is a free shuttle that runs from the Light Rail to the hospital on a frequent basis and there was an effort to create a nice esthetic to the area.   Plus, I get a giggle thinking about the fast that the last extension built onto Cinderella City is still standing, even, or perhaps especially, since it did not remain the high-end department store (The Broadway).  Instead it holds the Englewood Library, a small museum (or did a few years back)... and the city offices. The icing is the trolley car on display as you come into the main entrance, complete with the sculpture of the horse that used to step onto the back of said trolley for the downhill trip.  Yes, I know it has little to do with the subject as a whole... and while I have thought of a tie-in, looking at the surviving malls (and their placements), as well as some of the areas that partially adopted the mixed use zoning that still have issues... but this is a year-old video and I've probably babbled enough for one night.

I noticed something that this video from Climate Town and a couple of videos from Not Just Bikes miss out on, and that is the increasing pace of technology and our ability to innovate; additionally, something that I have also noticed is one glaring issue that Climate Town and NJB fail to point out, and that's overcrowding of cities.   In 2019, I spent a year living in Korea as a member of the U.S. Military. When I went out to Seoul and some of the surrounding metro areas, I noticed how overcrowded and overpopulated the city was. For comparison: Seoul, South Korea's Captial City, hosts roughly 50 million people, compared to my former home state of Oregon, whose entire population is approximately less than Seoul. Not to mention the land size of South Korea as a whole is less than the State of Oregon. Granted, South Korea only offers a few alternatives in terms of public transportation and is also very car-dependent. (Editors Note: I understand this point is anecdotal at best, but I wanted to include it as a frame of reference).  I think this point is essential. Making walkable cities ignores factors such as but not limited to: Population Growth and Population Influctuation, infrastructure costs, the cost and maintenance needed to be spent on apartments and high-density living areas, the cost of making these high-density areas efficient in the first place, and objectively what is the most important the concentration of wealth generation in high-density cities that leads to less development of more rural or suburban areas.   While suburban and single-family areas might not be the most efficient to build, they serve the purpose of transitory housing.   We need fewer "Why x is destroying y" videos and more "Can we make x more efficient and cheaper than y."   I also note that I have seen many videos like this make the argument: "Let's trade one dependency for another." ( I would like to add this caveat here and say that this might not be the intended argument this video is trying to make, but it still is essential to make it.)

Bags are used for milk in more remote and colder areas to allow the folks that make fewer trips to the store or dairy to freeze the milk and store it for longer. The bags can compress and expand with freezing instead of bursting. At least that is what my dad used to tell me when I was a kid in Michigan.

Some other people in these comments have covered a few advantages of bagged milk, but one I haven't seen is that bagged milk stays fresher for longer. Milk starts going off much faster as soon as you open the container. Bagged milk comes in a quantity of 4 L (~1 gallon) distributed across 3 bags. So, you open 1.33 L of milk, which will last you a few days, while the rest stays nicely sealed and fresher till you need it.

Bagging milk is actually pretty efficient (I'm Canadian so I have a bias here I will admit), it uses less plastic than cartons, which are a material that can't be recycled, it also stacks just fine, much like a sandbag, and since it's sealed, there's no spillage, you buy them is bigger bags each with 3 bags of milk in them, and then you take out one, put it in a container, cut the corner for pouring, and then lay the rest of the bag flat. It's cheaper and uses less material, and though it can't be recycled, much like just about any plastic, neither can cartons, which will definitely spill if you lay them flat after opening them. People hear "bagged milk" and immidiately reject it, but it's actually pretty good if you have an open mind.

On another tack entirely, re. 'the fight against climate change'. The Goyt Valley, in the Peak District of Derbyshire, in England, was carved out by a glacier. Glaciers stretched as far south as just north of London, and the ice cap over the centre of England was a mile thick. That was 10,000 years ago - a blip in geological and climatological time. Yet, now, even the Goyt Valley has a temperate climate.  Go back further, and the Thames Valley was sub-tropical.  Go back further still, and there was a lengthy time when the only part of the Earth which was *not* covered with ice was a narrow strip around the Equator. Fast forward to the Medieval Warm period - roughly 950 AD to 1250 AD - we had global warming, and the average temperature rose by 2 - 3 degrees C.  Did the Earth fry?  Was human, animal and plant life devastated?  Actually, quite the reverse;  *all* forms of life flourished.  The area of England called East Anglia (N. Essex, Suffolk, Norfolk, Cambridgeshire) was covered with vineyards, and English wine exports to France reached such a level that the King of France imposed heavy import duties to protect French winemakers! In the late 13th century, in the course of a single generation, temperatures dropped in East Anglia to a point where vines could no longer germinate, and farmers had to switch to growing arable crops instead (that rapid temperature drop applied across Europe, the North Atlantic, and the Arctic).  And, please note, any long term study of climate will show changes exceeding anything we've seen in our lifetimes, both in terms of absolute temperatures and rates of change - and none of them caused by man-made CO2 emissions. Even more to the point;  if the average global temperature does rise by 2 or 3 degrees C, that will merely bring it up to the *average* for a period between successive Ice Ages. Reflecting on all these entirely natural climate changes, I find it ludicrous that anyone thinks we can effectively "fight against climate change"! Time to face facts;  compared to natural cycles and forces (such as that nuclear reactor we call the Sun), our powers to affect the climate are minuscule.  The only rational course is to do what all species (including our own) have done since life began on Earth: "Improvise, Adapt and Survive".

A few years go I moved from a "colonial suburb" to a mixed use urban neighborhood in a different metro area. 2 years later, after not needing to drive anywhere, I ditched my car. On the rare times when I can't walk or use transit, I use a ride hail ... and my transportation budget is much smaller.  Within one mile, I have 6 supermarkets, a couple of drug stores, museums, theaters, and more restaurants, cafes, and small businesses than I can count. I can walk 2 miles through city parks to my office.   My neighborhood has a mix of 100+ year old single family houses, duplexes and triplexes, old and new mid-size apartment buildings. The houses are expensive, the multi-family units are not. The crime rate is lower than the city average. The large streets are being restructured to be more pedestrian friendly.  This is in America ... I'm in one of the cities that eliminated single family zoning. It's not perfect, but it's getting closer.

I once flew exactly over the US southern East coast (roughly FL-NY) on a beautifully clear day. I'm not an American and don't usually spend much time thinking about urban planning either, but it was interesting to see. Spent most of the flight looking at the typical American suburban lay out from above. Down South it was a bit mixed, 'normal' suburbs, nature areas and some undefined areas. Going North it started to look more uniform, winding roads and 'cul-de-sacs' for mile after mile. Then the last 300 miles or so, more urban views of old / high rise / high density building between the suburban standard. It was nice to trigger some thin-air-based thoughts about the historical and cultural development of such a land mass, by looking at it from 7 miles up.

More population density tends to mean more crowding, less space, more crime, more regulations, higher cost of living, etc. I live out in the country, probably about a 7-8 minute drive to the nearest store, and 30 minutes from a major metro area. I like having a big house on some land and not having my neighbors stacked on top of me. Non-Euclidean zoning, everyone live in a klein bottle But for real, this kind of thing is eye opening. After living in an apartment for 4 years, I felt SUPER trapped, I hated having wall neighbors in what felt like a rat box. After moving back to my parent's place in the suburbs temporarily (thank you rent inflation) I was so excited to feel like I had space again. After maybe 2 months of it, I realized I felt just as trapped and was deeply confused. What were my plans for the future? How can I be happy if I hate living in what are essentially the ONLY TWO OPTIONS for housing in the US?? This video made it click for me though. It wasn't the space I was IN, it was the space AROUND them. Both locations had nothing that was within either a reasonable/safe walking distance. And I realized I took the last year at the apartments for granted. Because what did the apartment owners do in that last year? They had a plot of land out front that was essentially a field between the apartment complex and the highway it was near. They built what was essentially a (very) small strip mall and rented the spaces to local businesses; there were a few restaurants (sandwhich shop, pizza place, seafood place and wine bar), a dry goods store selling local produce from a few nearby farms, a dentist and medical clinic, a barbershop, and a petfood store. I was so caught up in how sick I was of apartment living in the middle of nowhere, only looking back do I realize how much it started to feel like a COMMUNITY. These places, were right out front of the apartments, like 30 second walk, they can't have been built without anything in mind other than primarily serving the apartment people specifically, and these places were almost entirely staffed by people who lived in the apartments. You started to recognize neighbors hanging out at the bar in the sandwhich place or in the drygoods store, people started using what was left of the field nearby to organize picnics, soccer matches, pet meetups. All it was missing was a small grocery store and I likely would have only ever had to drive anywhere to either get to work or go to the nearby county park. Now I'm back in the suburbs and miserable again because the only thing nearby is more endless rows of vinyl sided houses

Sorry, couldn't disagree more.  High density living is horrible, suburbs are excellent.  It just depends on your perspective.  If you love being shoulder to shoulder with millions of strangers, always afraid of being mugged, living in cramped quarters with no backyards, no independence, no peace and quiet, then high density life is for you.  If you enjoy peace and quiet, then no.  At my Surburban house I don't have to walk to a park to BBQ a brisket in a 10 ft by 10 ft allotted space, surrounded by dozens if not hundreds of other BBQ spaces, I can BBQ in my backyard patio, in quiet comfort.  I can read a book under the shade trees, enjoying the sounds of birds and squirrels.  In a high density location, all I hear is car horns, people, people, people.   If my kids want to play football, there is plenty of room in the side yard, no need for them to hike to a park somewhere.    If you can design a mixture of high density and suburb, say a suburb with plenty of bike trails, nearby stores, parks, etc, that are within easy walking distance, under manicured trees, please do so.  But I think you'll find that it will be difficult to maintain store profitability unless either people can drive to them or they are surrounded by high density apartments.  Having a requirement that everything you need be within walking distance reduces the customer to store ratio to a low level, and therefore a low profit level.  Adding public transportation to increase the ratio sounds great on paper, but I've lived in that environment and in general public transportation both sucks and is dangerous.  The nearest equivalent are small country towns, but you know what is common to those town?  Low income, low standard of living.   I can see people being raised in high density places loving it, because it is what they are used to, and they've learned to ignore the downsides to high density living, but to me such a place is hell on earth.
This is a tall order, a very tall order. Will take decades (30 years) to get the policies put in place let alone developing and planning.  By that time its too late.

Former US American military previously stationed in the Netherlands (I also saw several of the "Not Just Bikes" guy videos).  YES, I agree we need to continue fixing the US zoning laws.  YES, suburbs are terrible.  Problem I have is neither you nor Bike Dude are painting the whole picture and all the facts folks need to know who will never live abroad and see for themselves.  Let's be clear.  Holland is not all sunshine, tulips, pannekoeken and organic blunts!  It has problems too - especially if you're currently a Dutch farmer protesting the nitrogen laws.   What if I told you I was rejected from living in two Dutch neighborhoods simply because I was "American."  Yes, the Nederlanders have zoning laws that restrict too many of any race or nationality from "concentrating" in neighborhoods.  That'd be racism and nationalism... the bad kind.  Turned out there were already two homes filled with pesky Americans in those "zones," and a third American family was "forbidden."  Why?  The short take is this zoning law is intended to "forbid" (their lawful terminology "verbieden") the polarization of racial groups together in neighborhoods - causing minorities to form (particularly Muslim Turks).  They call it their multicultural integration policy - "integrate" being the operative word here.  It's directed towards all immigrants, but some more than others (which doesn't explain why I - assigned there as a NATO allies - was subject to an immigration law, but that was the case). As for the housing available, I (and other US NATO military in my predicament) ended up commuting 2hrs round trip from my duplex in Eindhoven.  Didn't exactly help the emissions problem I know, but I did avoid eating their horse meat and enjoyed the biking.  I'm not down on the Dutch.  Not at all.  I love the people there and have many friends in Eindhoven - even sang and played my guitar at a Dutch wedding.  I saw a lot of things there I wish the US would do - maybe not mayonnaise on French fries, but a lot of other things.  I've got nothing against progressive new ideas and borrowing great ideas that are working in other countries, but let's be sure and study the quantifiable facts and do videos coving both sides of the pros & cons thoroughly.

I'm surprised and a bit disappointed that you didn't touch on tax laws as a prime driver of land use in the United States.  The mortgage interest deduction, capital gain tax exclusions for owner occupied real estate, and similar tax exclusions are all intended not only to tip the balance away from renting and toward home ownership, but also to encourage those who can afford it to continually trade up into larger properties.  Even if it means commuting 200 miles every day.  These tax breaks are touted as "encouraging home ownership", but they likely don't do much for first-time buyers anyway, as they suck up available land, materials, and finance away from economical housing and toward high-end McMansions in the suburbs.  Which bids up prices and negates the value of the tax breaks for entry-level buyers.  And the tax breaks are paid for on the backs of renters, who have the same high income tax rates but no corresponding deduction for housing.  All of this makes saving for a down payment that much harder, creating an actual barrier to home ownership instead of an incentive.  This may be the main difference between the U.S. and other countries.

Plus, more concerning than frustrating the elderly who can at least have something specially built, as a Christian and teacher, I believe that all the new housing without yards are insufficient habitat for raising healthy human offspring that need to be in contact with nature to learn about God and the spirit, to say nothing of temporal matters like science education and physical health. I mean community playgrounds are nice, but they cannot replace a child being free to run around in a safe outdoor space while Mom and Dad are busy, which is generally most of the time. It should be self-evident for at least anyone who knows God that healthy habitat for the children this world was created for is a far more critical issue than protecting the environment which is only as valuable as it's service to the people it was created for. Since children have no real power to fight for such needs, the government planners are effectively choosing insufficiency for them when they promote multifamily structures without decent-size yards. And I'm not even talking about a quarter-acre a piece, but even a few hundred feet of play space where a child could do a cartwheel, play in the sand, plant a garden, or climb a tree. And when a society doesn't take care of it's children's developmental needs, there will ultimately be deleterious consequences to that society.  So really, as the suggested vertical housing only serves young, childless adults well, it is one thing to allow developers to build the missing middle housing for those who want it or cannot afford better, or to pass along real added costs for infrastructure to those looking for more space, but pushing only vertical, high-density housing over other forms is just going from one ditch to the other, trying to unduly micromanage and control others' lives, which is what got us into this problem in the first place. It is also harmful to society as a whole.  As my roommate has quoted, a study once found that young adults preferred living in cities, mothers in the suburbs, and children in the country, while fathers weren't as picky (consistent with home being the spiritual domain of the wife). Can we please quit deciding which demographic's preferences are going to be served this time around and let families decide for themselves?  Thank you.  And while we're at it, does anyone else see possible continuation of ethnic discrimination in HOAs having the power to determine subjective choices like house color - preferences which are in large part cultural or even genetic?

Oh and ... bag of milk is one of two ways milk is provided in Denmark. The bags are made of plastic with a significant amount of chalk making them more environmental friendly then the multilayered tetrapacks (prismatic boxes). They come neatly stacked in plastic - reusable - boxes, can neatly stand side by side in your fridge, and have an air filled grip part that is deflated before going to recycling, so that you just have a thin sheet of "bag" to dispose. The only thing annoying about them is that the walls around the "outlet" tend to stick together after each use.

I moved from  Southern Ontario where we could get bags of milk (4L of milk split into 3 sealed bags). you drink these by putting the bag into a milk pitcher (bag slides right into it), and cut the edge open., to Saskatchewan, where I can only get 4L jugs.  With the 4L jugs, we sometimes have milk go bad before best before date, just because it has had so much contact with air from opening and closing etc. With the bags of milk, you only open 1/3 at a time, so you tend to have less spoiled milk over the years.  Example of bagged milk pitcher in Canada: https://media.freshdaily.ca/static/articles/20200910-milk-bag.jpg?w=2048&cmd=resize_then_crop&height=1365&quality=70

So, I'm one of these folks who finds it really difficult to live in proximity with others. *Really* difficult. Recently moved into, yes, a detached single-family home which is bigger than is strictly necessary and is inefficient in terms of land and energy use. But, that's what I wanted. Other people stress me the hell out, I can't deal with them, I need my walls and my sanctuary. I commute with a car, can't deal with most forms of public transit, and it works for me.  Yet, I could never live in one of these godawful remote suburban developments because I find them aesthetically hideous and they would take even my own isolating tendencies to the extreme. I just live in an old, kind of working-class neighborhood near the city of yeah, probably a bunch of R1 zoning. And also, not everyone is like me, and it would be really really weird if everyone was. Like we've created all of this infrastructure to support a bunch of pathological introverts, and most people aren't like that, and that's probably a good thing that they aren't. So no wonder we end up with social stagnation and dysfunction as a result, to say nothing of the other problems.  So even though I'm unlikely to ever live in a mixed-use urban space, I think lots of other people would greatly benefit from them. Not everyone wants to have a car to take care of and a lawn and all of this infrastructure to be responsible for. Lots of people want to live a much more minimalist life, want to be in closer community with others, want to walk and bike and take good public transit. And I'd love for there to be less congestion so I can zip around in my car more quickly if that's how I want to live.  The "American Dream" we're sold on is all about this detached home, isolated "castle" living. You're supposed to want this, we're really heavily conditioned to feel this way. But I think it should be about having the freedom to choose. We should have options for both, and honestly, if there were more dense, attractive shared urban spaces for people to live in, it would take pressure off of the housing market and folks like me would actually find it easier to find the homes we want. It doesn't have to be either/or, and the zoning laws should reflect how people actually want to live.

These videos prompted me to check out what my childhood town's zoning looks like. Its a medium sized city with a population of 100,000+ people. I was initially surprised when I saw that there was some "high density housing" allocated throughout the city. Then I decided to cross reference the zoning map with google street view to see exactly what neighborhoods those medium, high and very high density zones looked like. spoilers: it was kind of laughable.  medium density == detached suburbs, but all the houses are on the small side, single story, and squished a bit closer together then low density. Plus a hand full of duplexes and trailer parks. high density == row houses, attached on the sides but only a single story high very high density == two story apartment houses, maybe three story if its a poorer neighborhood.  For reference, I currently live on a university campus, My apartment building is a whopping four stories tall. A neighboring complex is five stories tall. Across the road are three story townhouses (that I'm a little disappointed I wasn't able to get into, they are lovely.) I don't actually now how these areas are zoned, because they technically aren't part of the city but the university. However, I have a grocery store within a ten minute walk along with (two?!) Starbucks, a bank, and a handful of restaurants. Further down the road is a mall that has a tiny little target and a movie theater, plus convenience stores and restaurants scattered across campus. If I _really_ want a snack or a drink, my apartment complex has a vending machine with drinks and snacks at reasonable prices outside the communal gym. I honestly really enjoy it. I think there's probably a reason that cities in Japan let people just slap vending machines pretty much where ever they want. Its a good alternative if there isn't enough demand for an entire store in a neighborhood, or enough space to put one. Put them in the parks along with a few trashcans and some seating and you have a very low cost neighborhood gathering point. Have one guy drive around to service the machines every day, collect change, check for damage or errors, restock, etc.  The lesson of this comment: even if your city seems to have a decent amount of high density housing, check to see what they mean by "high density". You might be surprised. Also vending machines are cool and America needs more of them. idk about Canada.

Here's a problem I see, specifically with the sorts of mixed use projects like the ones highlighted at the end of the video. South Park did a whole episode about why they don't turn out like they're supposed to: They're often racist and classist as fuck with the bottom lines of the developers placed above a commitment to the supposed design principles that underlay their creation, a la the SoDoSoPa parody neighborhood from that show. The sorts of mixed-used redevelopment initiatives we get in urban America usually take the form of gentrification that forces out the same sorts of generationally-impoverished racial minorities that redlining did a century ago (and which, as this video points out, essentially created the problem in the first place). Wherein they aren't pushing anyone out but rather repurposing wasteful greyfield spaces as is advocated for here, the only people who will likely afford to move in are the same sorts of middle-upper and upper class yupsters who participate in urban gentrification, mostly because municipal governments want to attract that sort of resident for both sociological and economic reasons. Unaffordable housing is institutionally entrenched in America. The white flight of the 60's and 70's still dominated the psyche of most urban planners who are more than willing to use "upscale" branding to try and kill any potential ghettoization before it grows. They also have a financial incentive to keep the rent high in order to satiate the developers, pay for the project, and boost the tax base to make it seem economically and political viable by the next year's budget reports (this is particularly true when, as the video also points out, we are in a political environment where septuagenarian NIMBY's dominate local politics and mixed-use urbanism is still viewed with skepticism on principle). Ultimately this makes such new mixed-use spaces inaccessible to minorities and the poor, thus making it neo-redlining by default of American socioeconomic shittiness.   This is just one more thing that the euro critics of lefttube like Not Just Bikes and Adam Something don't seem to get: even though much of the conscious American left agrees with your critiques, simple implementation of many of the "obvious-fix polices" seen elsewhere in the 1st/western world are not a political reality here. "You can't just [do xyz euro thing] in America" is a true meme, and no, it's not always just a matter of political willpower (municipal or otherwise). In some cases it's a matter of entrenched law like the Dillon Rule in the case of municipal autonomy, nigh-immutable Constitutional requirements in the case of, say, firearms, or deep-seated cultural and financial eco-racism (that then sometimes reflects in arcane local laws such as R1 zones) as is the case here. Combine these sorts of hard issues with the (in)famous paranoid style in American politics wherein people just simply don't trust the government (a sentiment so baked in that it's essentially part of our national mythos and civic religion and which is hard to fully understand unless you've lived here for some time), and you have *big* issues that *must* be dealt with, but that will all but *require* a cultural, economic, or even god forbid bloody revolution to fix or change on any timescale less than decades.  Of course, all of this is really just a function of the fact that this is all happening under capitalism, and further drives home the point that in order to sustainably and functionally implement many of the socioeconomic changes needed to combat climate change, we have to move away from capitalism as an economic system. Of course, there isn't really time to do that *before* we need to start taking mass climate action, and so the move towards post-capitalist society will need to happen slowly alongside (and mostly after) the climate change mitigation process, a process which will already be a civilization-altering change. The end result of this is that we will likely go through a period, at least here in America, of a sort of Green Racism wherein climate-smart socioeconomic changes will be reserved for those at the top and near-top in various kinds of White Bourgeois Climate Paradises at first. These will then also likely need to be shifted away from and democratized by further municipal activism and class struggle, much the same way as R1 zones will now. In other words, the US will probably have an Eco-Fascism phase of some sort because this country's entire culture is neurotic in a way that most Eurobros deeply underestimate.

I just want to say (because the video didn't make this clear, although I'm not saying it needed to)- there are many, many people on planning and zoning commission members that /do/ care deeply about, beyond ensuring the area functions from the things everyone agrees zoning is important for, walkability, living spaces, and generally making things better along the lines of this video. This is not to say there aren't members (or more generally, people in aldermanic or jurisdiction-equivalent positions) who also aren't also interested in keeping change from happening (sometimes they're the ones who provoke people to show up) but merely to say that showing up to these meetings, staying informed, and helping make sure your friends who live around you are aware of what's up makes a big difference in the long run (and the people on these commissions trying to make change happen will be incredibly appreciative)

You bring up some problems that definitely need to be addressed and did it in a fun and entertaining way however, I think there are quite a few other factors to add to the conversation. A major contributor to climate change is the methane created from food scraps in our landfills. I'm yet to see an apartment complex with a good system for taking in food scraps. Not to say that it couldn't happen, but currently, it's not a priority in their design. On the flip side, many of the people I know with single-family homes, have gardens and compost their food waste.   If an apartment complex was designed to incorporate food scrap collection along with a methane biodigester that generated electricity, heat, or cooking gas for the tenants then I could see it being a better option for those who like living in the city. But just living in an apartment alone doesn't solve climate change.   If the recent pandemic highlighted anything, it's that living on top of other people isn't always the best option either.   While the video discussed traditional stick frame homes, there are many single-family home designs that can be net-zero for energy usage using new insulation techniques, earth berms, etc. These would be great alternatives for those who want to have a positive impact, without living in the city.   Another zoning condition to add to the conversation is the minimum square footage for new home construction. Many people would elect to live in smaller, more affordable homes if they were legal. Tiny houses for example are illegal in many areas of the U.S. simply because the local governments collect property taxes based on the square footage size of homes, so reducing the size requirements of a home, means they will bring in less tax revenue.

Unfortunately this video is pretty biased. Single family homes do take up more land but that is about the only universally true point in this video.   Redlining isn't really a subject that belongs in a modern day conversation about the suburbs.   Energy efficiency is also wrong in many ways. I just moved from an apartment that was only 10 years old and reasonably well built to a new construction home in a new neighborhood development. It costs the same to heat and cool my 1800+ sqft house as my 1200 sqft apartment. I also have the ability to avoid using my AC and heating because I have a basement that stays warm in the winter and cold in the summer. Having 4 exterior sides to your dwelling also has the benefit of airflow if you open windows, apartments have 1 to 2 exterior walls which makes airflow difficult. I'll also be installing solar panels in just a few days(a decision none of my previous landlords would have done). As of right now, the energy needs of my house is already vastly less than any apartment I have ever lived in and will get even better.  The other benefit of suburbs is increased green spaces which help cool the neighborhood and convert some of those CO¬≤ gasses into oxygen.   I'm sure this isn't the case everywhere but the 75% single family dwelling rules makes sense in my neighborhood. It's build around a small commercial district with restaurants, stores, and a grocery store. That commercial district is mixed in with residential townhouses and 5 to 7 story apartment buildings, then as you move away from that it becomes single family homes once you move outside the walkable perimeter. As I'm sure you know, if you make a smaller circle that is 25% the size of a larger circle and put it inside the larger circle, that doesn't mean you have miles and miles of never ending suburbs from the neighborhood commercial hub.   Infact the amount of people you can squeeze into that 25% area is going to be nearly comparable to the population of the other 75% area of the single family houses. So saying that only 25% of new housing is being devoted to apartments/condos means that people who want apartments are being under served makes no mathematical sense.   Public transportation isn't just a problem in the suburbs, it's a confusing mess for most people everywhere. It's a public transport problem, not a suburban problem.  I think the biggest issues with your perspective on this subject is 2 things.   1) You trust landlords way more than you probably should. I mean, you don't really own or have any control over anything if you rent or even if you own a condo in a lot of ways, your living conditions are only going to be as good as your landlord/property manager. 2) You completely undervalue the importance of intergenerational wealth that comes along with home ownership. Eventually we're going to get old and need to go into expensive senior/assisted living. Selling a house is a massive part of being able to afford that without being a financial burden on your children or anyone else. Without it, you have far fewer options in life. The idea that I wasted so many years and so much money towards renting turns my stomach and it's kind of sad to see young people like yourself not realizing how big of a problem that is.

First, I'd like to point out there is nothing wrong with high rise development, 20-50 floor buildings really can maximize the viability of rail and walkability, in fact, townhomes may be inferior to them in that regard. The more density the more viable your rail options will be and the closer people will be to the things they need because you have more population in walking distance to support businesses. Europe isnt necessarily the best since some European cities actually have height restrictions, but if you want to maximize walkability you want unlimited density. Another thing is high rises can be better than townhomes because you have a view. Townhomes can actually have a more boxed in feel than being 30 floors up with a view you have an absolutely spacious feeling. The 50 floor buildings also can open up more room for greenspaces and parks which is really what increases the habitability. So you want 50+ floor buildings and then you want to use the saved space to put in parks and gardens with waterfalls etc.   Very interesting video. One of the things that also may promote R1 is ad valorem (property) taxes in the twisted logic of city and county governments. This is because that single family homes means what a single family owns has more value than if they lived in a high rise apartment building. That increases the amount of per capita taxable income. Thats why they might love the massive single family mcmansions. This holds until the county or city is completely paved over. An alternative is to not have property taxes on homestead and instead use income taxes, and also possibly creating municipalities as fixed sized blocks over existing urbanized areas. Those municipalities since they cannot annex and only have a fixed amount of land they likely instead will opt for high density to maximiize theiir tax bases.   Another tool is minimum density  and unlimited density areas that are required to be expanded acording to housing demand studies which essentially forces enough housing to be built and to be built high density.   Another tool is Urban Growth Boundaries that can work with the above and abolishing the R1 and allowing demand mandated unlimited density and minimum density zones which stops urban sprawls and forces residential development up, rther than out.

This is a very well researched and very well made video. Kudos. However, I have some criticisms. I'm a home builder and have been in both residential and commercial construction for about 3 decades and while I'm not an expert on zoning and planning, it is very complex and difficult to get right. Single Family Residences are extremely resource inefficient and, generally speaking, higher density housing is preferable. But it is way more complicated than just changing the zoning laws to allow more types of housing in the suburbs. I think it can roughly be described as driving from one's home versus walking or biking from one's home. Sure, most like the idea of living in a "walkable" neighborhood but it is drastically more difficult for these neighborhoods to be created.   Let's say that a mixed use development with 5 story apartment buildings is ideal for housing efficiency. Building the apartments is the easiest part. Selling them is the extremely difficult part. For a person or a family to invest in a residence in a mixed use development they must be confident in the surrounding services being there so that they don't have to get in their car and drive to them. The developer of a mixed use neighborhood has to get the right balance of housing and services. They need to provide emergency services like police and fire and medical. They need to make sure there are the right mixes of elementary, middle and high schools. They need to provide the right amount of shopping options and somehow provide competitive forces to keep prices affordable and ensure quality customer service. They need to ensure that there are restaurants and entertainment options for the residents. And how do you ensure that the restaurants are any good, or that there is enough diversity? A nice condo or townhome could be built but no one will buy it because the schools are too far away, there is no grocery store within walking distance and the few restaurants in the neighborhood are really just bars and aren't family friendly. And there needs to be high paying jobs that people can walk to. The jobs are probably the biggest difficulty because it is nearly impossible to get the housing, schooling, shopping, entertainment and employment mix all balanced to where people don't need to travel in and out of the neighborhood.   There are also the infrastructure challenges. Placing a dense housing development out in the suburbs requires different roads, electricity, water, gas and sewer designs compared to less dense housing.  So yes, the suburban zoning approach of single family residences is the easiest and safest path; not necessarily the best one. But planning and building the best one is extremely difficult and extremely risky. I challenge anyone to provide some examples of high density neighborhoods that are affordable, have good schools, have diverse employers, and have good shopping, restaurants and entertainment within walking distance. Oh, and have parks and trails and connections to the outdoors. It is very difficult and very, very rare (if it exists at all).   I think higher density housing should be encouraged but it probably works best within the current suburban landscape. Zoning should set aside more land for apartments, condos and townhomes and cluster them around the planned commercial areas and plan for some good linkage between them. Trying to do a lot of mixed use developments will probably lead to a lot of failures because they are very difficult to do well.

It's interesting to me that you chose the Solterra neighborhood for many of the 'suburban hell' shots. Solterra was planned to be more like BelMar than Highlands Ranch, but a band of angry Boomers killed it. When Solterra was planned, it included a lot of high-density buildings. In fact, there are a large number of row homes in the neighborhood's SW corner. The community had planned to include hundreds of apartments along with a walkable town square-esque area on the west side in what is currently known as "Red Rocks Business Park." However the xenophobic voters of older parts of Lakewood passed an ordinance severely limiting the number of new dwellings allowed each year, prioritizing single-family builds. This put the mixed-use, higher density, walkable neighborhood plan on ice.

A little bit of elaboration on the "4 walls leaking more energy" graphic: Apartment complexes typically have, at least nominally, "four walls". So there's nothing wrong with the "McMansion" insofar as building structures of their scale, the problem is that there are too damn few people living in them to justify the  amount of energy it takes to maintain climate control. What makes apartments more efficient is the amount of shared walls between tenants and the greater density of  people being served by a given amount of energy spent on maintaining interior climate.

I will say, I had to move out of the city due to it being twice as costly, for rent/mortgage, utilities, pollution, crime, heat island effect & my favorite: noise.  The rents are extreme (a 1000sqft condo costs twice what a 1000sqft SFH does). The utilities are double (my winter bill peaked at over $600/mo vs $250/mo for the same sqft, water bill halved & my taxes dropped another 3%). The pollution - you could see the soot on the windows (no fresh air in the city) - 'nuf said. Crime became ridiculous (it went up 400% in the place I was at in just 10 years). Then we have the noise.  Working from home, the noise (mostly bass & sub-bass from hiphop & EDM - no offense to that style of music, but, even as a bass player, it really grates on the nerves to hear it almost continually) was getting unbearable.  Just moving 10 miles away from the city, the heat island effect disappears (it's, on average, 5 degrees warmer in the summer in the city than just a few miles away). As a German I never before knew about the US American zoning regulation and its origin. I would like to add: You either plan a city for cars which resembles a spiral by using up ever more space on its fringes for the necessities of driving and parking or you plan a dense city for walking amended with a light-rail or something like that for greater distances. These two concepts do not harmonize with each other. Or you build a car-dependent city with some walkable neighborhoods as a foul compromise. These walkable neighborhoods are in Europe known as the "old town". The "old town" is usually where tourists flock to to visit. In newer developing countries there is a palpable lack of enjoyable neighborhoods as anything is planned to be accessed by cars even though most people there do not have a car.

HOLY SHIT. Single Family Zoning is the single *MOST* annoying and irritating code regulation that exists.   Here in Chicago the number of formerly legal housing units in existing multifamily homes is STAGGERING and the city for some reason LOVES to de-legalize units whenever they get the chance. It's insane.   Not only does this hurt business owners who are trying to make enough money to justify ownership of such buildings, but the deficit in housing space drives up cost of living everywhere.   And why do we do this? Well, I'm guessing it's because "OH NO, density!" As well as pricing out minorities, and because we're trying to... keep a suburban feel in a *giant hyperurban city?* Yeah it makes zero sense.   This is why recently the Chicago city council has been trying to do this ADU ordinance in an effort to revert many of these former legal living spaces back to legal living space. But of course, with rent control, rent ceilings, and plenty of other ways to control landlords every which way than they did before. And they haven't even succeeded in passing the ordinance city wide beyond "pilot areas" and the process for getting these ADUs certified is arduous. In the meantime, the city is still going around and classifying obvious multifamily homes as single family, and then making these landlords have to go to court and present proof that the new zoning is incorrect... I mean this isn't the only way they pull shit like that either. Another city favorite is to change the zoning or number of legal units unbeknownst to owners during sale tie transfer, or even more common, when an owner is taking out a permit to make changes or fix something (yet another draconian requirement).   America's zoning laws and politicians are so fucking frustrating. I know and appreciate what we have here, but I'm still gonna be frustrated at obvious inefficiencies, obvious money grabs, racist policies, and nonsense regulations. When will people have had enough? I don't even know how deep the roots of this issue are but I just got so enraged by this crap.... It's not even funny.

Rollie, I've said this to 'not just bikes' as well - single family housing is THE best way to live.  All the flaws you point out with suburbia are spot on. But it doesn't change the fact that if I have a choice, I will choose single family living every time.  Why?  Between my wife and I, we have 8 bicycles.  A motorcycle.  Two cars.  We need a garage, and you can't have than in an apartment building.  We also really like having a yard.  We like not having anyone live above/below/beside us.  AND we need our cars to do the things we like to do.  My parents are a six hour drive away - I'm not taking a bus to go see them.   We like to take our bikes to the mountains, and to distant event, again, taking the subway is not an option.  Point being, even if we did live in an apartment, we'd still need our cars.  Oh, and for you know, TO GET TO WORK.  (Actually, we both work close together and car pool.  It's a 15 mintue trip by bike/bus/car.  We still drive.  Why, because my work requires me to drive to jobsites - again, the bus/bike won't work).  You and NJB seam to think the magic bullet is 'high density housing'.  Well, high density housing sucks.  In college I lived in a frat, a dorm, and an apartment.  So I know what that lifestyle is.  You can't crank your music.  You have to listen to other people thumping around.  There's no place to put all your stuff.  You don't have a backyard.   - I'm not trying to shit on your parade, as I too think sprawl will be the death of us.  But you have to focus on finding solutions that make single family living the prominent form of living.  Zoning is the answer.  But you can't just say "change all zoing so we have to build the netherlands everywhere".  The key to making zoning work to have the right mix of "travel time".  By that I mean every single family house should be within walking distance (5 blocks) to at least a couple commerical locations (restuarant, business, shop) so that "x" percentage of trips can be done on foot/by bike.  This way at least some of people trips are walkable/bikeable.  And because you now have all these little commercial pods spread throughout the city, another "x" percentage of trips are short trips (5 minutes by car).  This minimizes traffic.  If done right, 80% of all a person's weekly needs can be done by walking/bike/5-minute car rides.   (And in this mix there will be 'some' high density living - duplex's, apartments, mix-used, etc.  But they'll be secondary...)

Great video, I would also argue that dense cities are also the other problematic equation! Urban economics find that all else equal, residents often choose denser, more walkable neighborhoods. Poor planning in dense cities that do not build more housing is the critical push factor that encourages people to move to suburbs. I live in the UK, and recently moved into a three-bedroomed flat (apartment) with my husband and son, right next to the main town. I can honestly say it's the best thing I ever did; everything we need is well within walking distance, yet the flat itself looks over a small stream and woodland area at the back. As someone who doesn't drive, this is a godsend to me. If I need to carry three bags of shopping home on my own, I know the walk back is less than three minutes and along a flat road with wide pavements and ample safe crossing places, so it's perfectly doable. If our family wants to eat out, whether during the day or late in the evening, again, it's a short stroll into the town, and there are two beautiful parks to visit within fifteen minutes walk away, along with gyms, a cinema, a theatre, a library, a museum... and of course there are well-maintained bus and train services, again within a short walk, to travel to other areas further out.  I've never understood the appeal of those sprawling suburbs in the middle of nowhere; sure, you get your own, detached house and garden, but for me, they'd start to feel like my own personal prison if that's literally all there was within walking distance.

Speaking as a dasher, I've worked in an area that are mixed zone like you mentioned.  It was one of my favorite spots because everything was really close and the offers would be consistently good.  They also look so much nicer as well.  I live in north Carolina, and one of those towns is in Cornelius.  Its like a 30 minute commute to drive there, but worth it.  And I always feel so incredibly comfortable in the area.  Suburbs tend to pose a huge logistics problem for delivery jobs, since suburbs are often so far away from most restaurants.  It's not only a problem for drivers but the customers as well, who not only have to bid more to get their offers accepted, but wind up with lukewarm food once they do secure a driver just because of the distance the dasher or gig driver has to take.  And suburbs are windy, have strict speed limits, speed bumps, and can be confusing to exit after the job is done.  And while I prefer delivering to houses as apartments present even worse problems most of the time, the draw back is having to deal with the distance round trip that eats into your profits or forces you to be incredibly selective about what you will and will not take

While I don't disagree with much in this video (many zoning laws are ridiculous and bad), I do want to share a few thoughts. I think it is fair to point out that the suburbs were, to my knowledge, created before the energy crisis began to be recognized, possibly creating the crisis or exacerbating it. Many older urban structures had similar energy efficiency issues.  I have heard of initiatives in recent years to remedy that, including solar panels and renovations to tighten up insulation to reduce energy consumption. The house I grew up in has had such renovations.  I grew up in a smaller town on the edge of a metro and prefer the wide open spaces. Having to drive 30+ minutes to get to a major urban/commercial area was definitely a drawback. I also lived in a major city (Minneapolis) for a time and the driving situation was identical.   I like the idea of greener, lower automotive traffic urban areas. However, I worked as a delivery driver on the U of M campus which had such areas and some of the buildings were virtually inaccessible by automobile, making deliveries difficult and time consuming. Not good when delivering fresh, hot pizza to hungry college students. There is also the issue of gentrification.  I would absolutely prefer to work within walking distance of my home (or from home). Businesses go where the people are, so if this trend of de-urbanization continues, we could see the revival of smaller, self-sustaining towns (small-town America) thus breaking up these large, hideous blocks of concrete and steel known as cities and facilitate the return of the green.

Regardless, if anything, I would hope the increase in telecommuting revives existing small-towns, but suburbs aren't going anywhere. Definitely more of that should be available for people that want it.   Also, many suburban developments in my area are already zoned for both townhomes/twinhomes and SFHs. They are usually constructed with the apartments or townhomes closest to the major road/entrances to the development, with the homes then tucked further away.

I grew up in a large single house on a major road. Across the street was a grocery store. We only went there to get things like milk, bread and eggs. Everything else we drove across town to all the other stores depending who had what on sale. If the store across the street had a sale on, we would drive there on are way home so we wouldn't have to carry everything to the house, just in from the car. As a kid i walked all over the neighborhood until I was 6 and got my first bike. I'd ride around the neighborhood but if I needed to go further, I'd get my parents to take me in one of their cars. When I was 16, thank god I got my drivers license and now I could drive myself where ever I needed. Almost never rode my bike again. The street in front of our house was the main road through town,  and I was taught at an early age that to watch out for traffic. Also, when I was a kid, unlike today it seems, cars had the right of way, even in parking lots. Don't walk out in front of cars unless you want to get run over. I hate buses as they are loud and noisy. I like driving and an hour in the car is nothing. I love shopping centers, not downtowns. I hate walking further than I have to. When I have to go downtown and shop or run errands, I have to continually move my car to get close to where I need to go because I will not walk more than a block for anything. Growing up there were many fast food restaurants within about 4 or 5 blocks from our how. Did we ever walk, NO, we would drive to any of them and back. I like how so many people respond to this video by saying the "like living in suburbs". Not really considering they may not actually like suburbs, it's just the only life they've ever known, and alternatives are weird and scary to them.   Moreover, because in America there's no space between Single Family Detached Suburb and Dense Urban Center With Poorly Maintained Infrastructure, they assume that anything that's not the former is the latter. Whereas if things like duplexes, triplexes, townhouses, and small apartment blocks were allowed to exist, they would occupy that "Missing Middle".  It's also difficult for them to imagine an alternative to car-dependent communities, nor the benefits from living in a place where all the locations you'd want to visit would be in walking or cycling distance. Doubly so if there's safe and effective bike infrastructure (which also doubles as walking infrastructure). Imagine how much more money your average family would have if they didn't pay nearly as much on gas or car repair bills. Imagine how much healthier they would be if they could walk or bike everywhere easily.  Imagine how much more freeing it would be to have the option of whether to drive or not.  That's ultimately what advocates of mixed-use zoning laws want. Not to force everyone to leave the suburbs and live in townhouses or apartment buildings. Just giving people the freedom to do so. To not make people walk or ride a bike everywhere, but to make that an option.  Who knows, you may even discover you like it. That, in fact, you hate suburbs, and always have.

Yo y'all need to a video on Lifestyle Islands. I used to live in buffalo ny and am used to interconnected parking lots. For an example look at parts of Transit road: if you really wanted to, you could go pretty far down Transit without TOUCHING designated street, because all the 99 little shopping plazas have access through each other's parking lots. In the 20teens I moved to California, near a developing shopping area with a street down the middle. But it was developed in 6 stages, and each stage was blocked off from the other, in their own little islands. This means Aldi and Wal-Mart are right next to each other, but in order to go from one to the other I can't just walk next door because Wal-Mart was built up on an embankment that has a high iron fence separating each store's personal space. So instead of the 5 minutes it'd take walking, I have to take my car and fight 20 minutes of traffic (another contention point because this plaza was built in an area oversaturated with single family housing so everyone and their mom used this plaza as a "shortcut" but if everyone uses a shortcut it's not a shortcut anymore) just to go one store over.
PLANNING...that's the operative word.  I live in an area that used to be farmland.  Granted, 20+ years ago when we moved here, it was to move into a single-family home in a small subdivision.  For 20+ years, it remained a somewhat quaint, quiet area...accessible stores, no traffic, low crime, countryside...just a great place to live.  Then, folks in the city started to catch wind of how nice it was out here, and they started moving here in droves.  Now...I'm not so much against that if  -- IF -- anything that resembles PLANNING (there's that word again) is done before just throwing up another cheap subdivision to quell the masses.  Everything is sprawled very far apart, in some areas there aren't sidewalks so you can't safely walk or ride a bike to the store...you're required to get in a car to get there.  Multifloor apartments are right next to single-family subdivisions, stores are plopped down into areas that make absolutely no sense, etc.  Traffic is now terrible, stores are now packed at all hours of the day.  There's virtually no "land" anymore...it's all homes, roads, and stores.  You can't go outside without someone's dog barking at you...and there's an almost never-ending wailing of sirens...someone getting pulled over by the cops, an ambulance, a fire truck, etc.  ALL.... THE....TIME.  I love well-planned communities, where just able everything is walkable (or at least bike-able)...but our city planners must've missed school on the day they taught actual planning.  I've gone to planning meetings before, and they're an exercise in futility...one Karen trying to out Karen another Karen.  I don't have much hair left, I fear that continued participation in these meetings will result in absolute and complete baldness.  For these reasons, we're exploring our options of packing up and moving somewhere FAR away (within the next 5 years) far from anything that might succumb to urban sprawl in OUR lifetime.
There's some video essay somewhere also pointing that American suburbs don't make sense not only "merely" in terms of certain conveniences, and reduced environmental damage, but also in terms of finances, with suburbs not paying for themselves, tax-wise, and so forth. And also not covering their maintenance costs, requiring further developments in a somewhat pyramidal-scheme.

There's a few things you're overlooking.  The #1 co2 producing human activity in the world is creating concrete, steel and glass.  For concrete it's a 1 to 1 ratio.  Creating 1 ton of concrete releases 1 ton of co2 into the atmosphere. High density metropolis's while convenient for plumbing and mass transit, create more co2 than they sequester.  #2 these buildings do not sequester carbon like a wood frame 1 family house would.   The best way to offset carbon is to build as off-service as possible in the lowest density possible.  Wood frame/Timber housing, self sufficient with each house raising their own food, only relying on stores as a supplement.  Even on my smallish 1/5th acre house in the suburbs, I grow enough vegetables and can them to sustain about 50% of our veggies for the year. Septic leach fields provide not only sewage treatment, but a rich source of nutrients for plants.  Finally, we need to stop tearing apart our natural co2 scrubbers (Looking at you Brazil) Deforestation is reducing out ability to scrub and sequester carbon.

Sure, cities may be technically more efficient, however you are overlooking a number of things:  1. Apartments aren't economically efficient (it's pretty well-known that buying a home is an extremely good investment) and involve dealing with extremely unfair leases. 2. If I'm going to OWN a home, I shouldn't be SHARING any part of that property with anyone else. The walls of MY home should be wholly owned by ME and not shared by some other property. 3. Having shared walls greatly reduces privacy and (as anyone who's lived in an apartment can attest to) means you have to often deal with noisy neighbors, or maybe you are the noisy neighbor, or maybe both. 4. Much of the sustainability problems listed aren't unsolvable. America has so much spare land that we might as well use is, and nice quiet housing seems like a good use of the resource. Farms can be build vertically to vastly increase density to start with. If anything, it's farms that should be going into the sky and not the housing. We can develop sustainable asphalt that doesn't harm the environment and build sewer systems designed to handle any excess water that develops as a result of the suburban development.  Also, as someone who grew up in a suburb, we were maybe a mile from pretty much all of our basic needs and within 20 minutes of things like malls and theaters. I honestly had more trouble getting around to places when I lived in a city and had to cope with all the shitty traffic than I did living in a suburb.

Alright.... a bag of milk is a thing in India because it is cheaper to produce and quick to.....bag. We have something called a co-operative system where milk from local farmers is collected at multiple locations within a village, shipped to a pasteurizing plant close by, pasteurized and "bagged" on the same day and ready for consumption by the next day. These are shipped to retailers close to the pasteurizing plant itself so that it don't have to travel long distances. Reduces transportation costs, production costs and ensures a steady fresh supply for the hundreds of millions who consume it daily. Also butter milk and yoghurt from local farmers are supplied this way. They don't have sophisticated bottling plants at their homes. So either you can go to their farm with a bottle to collect it or you can go to a local store and get these "bagged" buttermilk/yoghurt.

Milk bags came in when Canada went metric. It was because manufacturers had to keep making quart containers for the US market and making liter containers as well would be too expensive. You get a pitcher designed for the bag, slide the bag into the pitcher and snip off a corner.
