14:53 you mention "bags of milk" as a bad idea, but the reason behind it is to use the least materials possible and make production easier, as opposed to card board milk boxes. The bags are put by the consumer in reusable plastic containers which allows to stack in in the fridge. Also in South America and Europe, for example, milk companies put some type or natural preservative which allows for the milk to not go bad or spoil for months even if left out side of the fridge, it's amazing this is not used in USA or Canada yet, this shows Milk companies want the milk to go bad as fast as possible one purchased by the consumer forcing to buy more milk by short life-time frames regardless if used or not.

I would like for us all to get average travel distance to less than 4 miles a day before 2050.  In less than 100 years we will have to decide to stop burning fossil fuels or die.  When we are eventually forced stop burning fossil fuels 90% of people will be unable to walk to work, food, or any kind of shopping and the economy will take a permanent nosedive.  We still have time now (and the ability to still burn fossil fuels safely) to reduce the average travel distance by a couple of percent every year until we won't need to travel that far.  In fact, if we could get the average travel time per day for everyone to less than 4 miles a day, we could still drive fossil fuel cars for the next few hundreds of years without destroying the planet.  Think about that for a minute.  No new technology, just make smaller inner-city walkable communities. We had milk in bags when I was growing up. It was actually a really well-thought-out way of transporting a liquid. The packaging was extremely low-waste. It gets made fun of because, yes, you had to buy into the system by purchasing a plastic jug that fit the bags, and yes, it took a bit of practice to learn to cut the corner of the bag to form a spout the right size. Bags got replaced by plastic jugs and plasticized-cardboard cartons, which take way more energy to recycle. Oh, and because those bags were made to contain liquid, they were really heavy duty, and could be reused for all sorts of things. They weren't flimsy like grocery bags, so they weren't single-use. I'm not saying that milk in bags could have saved the planet...but the thinking behind it is the kind of thinking these issues need.

In case you've never heard or thought about it, the carbon that fools like this guy worry about was once in the air before.  The earth was warm and pleasant then and both plant and animal life flourished.  These life forms used the carbon, which is a natural substance, to grow and breathe.  The earth was not "burned to the ground" then, as this guy says may happen now.  Over time, by natural processes, this carbon became trapped in the ground and we are just releasing some of it back into the air when we burn fossil fuels.  This burning is basically a form of recycling that enriches our atmosphere and we should not turn our world inside out in an effort to reduce its occurrence.  We are far smarter than the creatures who lived with the carbon just fine before.  There's no need to panic.  And so far, since the Industrial Revolution, our lives have mostly improved.  The earth not only hasn't flooded, but the amount of dry land has actually increased.  We live longer.  We are richer and can travel more.  The weather, if anything, has gotten a little nicer. Interesting that Not Just Bikes didn't mention the still current practice of racist redlining in the Netherlands (Rotterdamwet / Wet bijzondere maatregelen grootstedelijke problematiek, and the 'Leefbaarometer'). The percentage of people of migrant background is used as a negative indicator of the living quality in a neighborhood. If a neighborhood is deemed to have a low quality of living (a high percentage of people of migrant background), it becomes redlined for people making less than a certain income, or for development of social housing, housing for seasonal migrants, homeless shelters, shared domestication, etc. This means that poor people, migrants and people of color are forced out of these neighborhoods, while developers come in and build expensive homes.

We have zoning reform in New Zealand. So you can pretty much build town houses within 800m walk of a bus stop or train station for several years. But also, you have always been able to build duplexes, and rowhouses on a section 3,4,5, or 6 houses, typically with one or two bedrooms each.   I used to own a suburban apartment, there were 12 units on three levels. Now I live in a house, which has infill housing, so there is a house in my back yard, that a retired lady lives in, we share a driveway, we independently own our own houses, and have legal entitlement to use our own sections as we want, but we cant park in the shared part of the driveway, it makes the density of the suburb higher.   Also in New Zealand there are convenience stores in suburbs, we call them dairys, because you can buy milk there, some of them are just a remolded old house. Also, the dairy might be in a row of shops, so there could be barber, a liquor store or a hamburger place, in walking distance, that's just about every suburb in the country. Sometimes a spare shop in a row is remodeled into a flat. It's crazy!, you can change it up.

A Bag of Milk is far more environmentally friendly then any other sort of carton!  Does this guy seriously not know what a "milk jug" is?  I guess not, so: It's a container that you put the milk bag into, then you cut the corner off the milk bag and use that hole as a pour spout.  This means that you are able to re-use the rigid plastic jug over and over again for like 10-20+ years; which means that far less packaging is wasted per litre of milk, less plastic, less cardboard, so yeah, a bag of milk.

Bagged milk is awesome! That is always how I buy it.  It takes less material to make a 4L bag of milk vs a 4L jug. It's also slightly cheaper. Furthermore, it keeps it fresher: if I open a 4L jug, I expose all the milk to the air whereas a 4L bag is subdivided into three 1.33L sealed subbags. I only expose 1.33L at a time keeping the rest of the milk protected from oxygen and fresher.

Higher density housing is a good idea until you have to live there. I come from an East Asian city where high density neighborhoods are the norm. Not sure why higher density = better to live in, because it's objectively worse. Most families have a car, except parking is expensive and restrictive. Also, driving becomes a lot slower and more dangerous thanks to the high density. The usable living space is A LOT smaller than even the smallest American detached house. Say goodbye to any sort of privacy, and if your neighbors are doing minor renovations or just assholes, then good luck. Walking to school isn't any easier, the stores surrounding the neighborhood are usually not as well stocked, so one still has to commute to shop. Admittedly, the detached house I live in  now is pretty convenient as suburbs go. However, the quality of life is much better than in Asia. So what if life is a bit more car dependant? I would commute by car back in Asia eventually - one can only take so much public transportation, even if it's reliable.   One thing I don't like is the lack of home businesses in America. In Asia, everyone living on the first floor of any complex/tower block would operate some kind of business, even the elderly. That's not the case in NA suburbs. Suburbs would be a lot more liveable if more home businesses existed.

Bags are "electrically sealed" (like meat in vacuum bags,) each bag has 1 liter (around 61 cu in) and there are small plastic jars where you put the bag in and cut one or two edges of that bag. Also drinkable yogurt and chocolate are sold in the same kind of bag. There are also other options, like plastic bottles and tetrapak boxes (those boxes which are a nightmare for recycling, a sandwich of thin cardboard and aluminum sheets glued together.)  Zoning in Brazil is determined by the municipality, and as far as I remember, the only limits there we usually have is regarding the number of stories, minimal size for each room, how much area cannot be built upon, distance between buildings and such. It might have something like USA R1 zoning code somewhere in very wealthy neighborhoods, but it's like a very small percentage of the total urban area. Here where I live I'm a single family house owner crammed into a neighborhood full of 7-10 story buildings, as we moved here nearly 50 years ago. In the late 1970's there was a milk farm two blocks away from my house and the tallest building was the police headquarters with 5 floors.
This ain't rocket science. Follow the money. You will see where things end up. All in the ever deepening pockets of fewer and fewer, and wars and feudalism for the rest. Have a nice day.

Interesting for this European to see an American reflection on residential sprawl. In France there is a law on 'zero net soil artificialization'. All new urban development requires densifying already built up areas, including those with single-family housing, or reclaiming brownfields or compensating new developments by  'rewilding' previously urban areas. However, residential sprawl has already taken its toll. 'European' central city living (with multi storey residential buildings joined together with shops and businesses on the first floor) is still a coveted although expensive thing in the larger urban areas (Paris, Lyon, Bordeaux) but many historic city centers are declining because of businesses and residents having moved towards the town peripheries.

One of the core premises of your video is demonstrably and unequivocally wrong.  Trends show that people prefer lower-density single-family housing.  When you compare condo to single-family sales, even when there is availability the sale times and margins for condos are directly and inversely proportional to how many neighbors they share.  Duplexes and townhomes see similar trends, with the salability of the units being directly tied to unavailability or unaffordability of the area single family homes.  While the sprawl problem does need a solution, the solution is better urban planning with better focus on alternative transportation, not forcing people into higher density housing with a bunch of other people who would rather have privacy and space instead of being cooped up like poultry being fattened in terrible conditions for slaughter.

Milk bags have lower environmental costs than cartons, don't they? Tetra pak, layers of paper and metal combined with plastic must be more complicated and expensive to produce, pack, and either recycle or dispose of. Milk bags are just one piece of plastic. You buy it in the store, cut a hole on two corners (the other one allows for airflow so the milk doesn't spill everywhere when pitching), and put it in a specific milk bag-holding jar/pitcher (another simple piece of hard plastic that lasts for a lifetime, but for some odd reason you always have more than one at home, and you never ever use the other one). We had that under state socialism in Hungary, and well after it, but nowadays western style cartons replaced them. While they co-existed, bagged milk was always cheaper than cartoned milk.

I basically spent the first half of my life in Europe. It's not as "fun" as Americans like to think. For one thing, most of Europe is actually "zoned" pretty much the same way as an American suburb. They call it "village" over there and it's basically an upgraded medieval row of farmhouses, barns and stables. There may be one shop, which has close to nothing to sell except for bags of milk and the occasional rye bread and (rarely fresh) baloney. If you want to buy anything else, you either hop onto the bus that leaves at 9am in the morning and comes back at 3pm in the afternoon or you get into your car and you drive ten miles to the next "town", which is a village with a school and a shopping mall. Cities are better, except that now you don't have parking for your car, but at least the buses are operating on a more frequent schedule. Just don't miss the last one or you have to sleep on the park bench until the next morning. Been there, done that. Fun! ;-)

Bag of Milk: This is wildly used in large industrial settings. I used to make ice cream at the Salt N Straw factory and all of the base/cream was in bags. This made it very, very easy to open and pour into machines or buckets and drastically cut down on overall product waste.  Otherwise, bags of milk were only good for throwing at friends.

Thanks for this - interesting and thought provoking.   The basic premises - that suburbs are bad news for the environment and that zoning is too rigid a concept for now - is beyond doubt really.  BUT..... what you do about it is far less clear.  Attempts to instigate high density housing in many countries has had very mixed results - often such developments start out okay, but end up as, effectively, slums.   Also, the characteristics of the societies concerned needs to be taken into account when making major changes in housing policy.  For example, what works for the socially minded, highly disciplined Japanese may not to be a great fit for Americans with their, shall we say, highly individualistic outlook?  Personal economic factors also come into play - to have different statuses of people living side by side is fine, but probably works best in societies without massive disparities in citizen income. The size of those disparities has a proven link to crime levels and America has some of the highest stats in both those cases.  So, yes change is definitely needed and if the right kind of developments could be encouraged, then positive benefits might flow, but for America to simply copy other countries may not work out well.   In the UK - in the 1990s - there was a new kind of suburb championed by a group of people headed by Prince Charles (famous for his barbed comments on modern architecture). This new kind of suburb included mixed housing - not just detached, but semi-dets, apartment flats and communal spaces. It included schools, shops, churches, meeting placed and of course pubs and had good public transport links AND small businesses are encourage to startup there.  The prototype development for this was at Poundbury in Dorset UK (see wikipedia page) and the concept has been extended to other developments in other parts of the UK since then. While it is still a suburb, it aims to negate a lot of the negative characteristics which you, Rollie, highlight here.

One issue often swept under the rug that comes with mixed zoning of this type, however, is that land tends to simply increase in price as a result for the whole area, meaning most young people get priced out of ownership to the profit of a few land owners building cheap appartments rented at sky high prices because of the ''convenience'' of the new city layout. This is a situation often favoring monopolistic markets and previous owners where new would be buyers are unwelcome. This means young people just get to suck it up.  European or Japanese zoning is by no stretch of the imagination a perfect solution. Renting in many of those ''ideal'' cities is often ridiculously expensive and owning a unit in them is prohibitively more expensive than just building a single family house on a suburban plot, all of this with the added complexity of having to deal with issues renovating anything in your block and having to deal with the same problems people face while living in appartments.   Japanese appartments also certainly don't have the reputation of being very spacious, something that is very much an issue for large families. As it happens, the population crisis of Japan is only worsened by the unavailability of housing at low cost per area because many would be families simply don't have the money to upgrade to larger appartments or single family homes in those mixed zoning areas. This reduces the amount of newborns coming to support the increasingly fragile economy of an older and older population because people try to keep some living standards by not having 2+ kids in a 1/2 bedrooms appartment.  This utopian dream of having most people living in dense ''optimised'' cities is very unpractical and problematic to say the least. The environmental cost of suburbs is only one factor to consider, there are other social and economic factors to consider too.

This is a really good, well made informative video about the tragedy that is urban sprawl in North America. It is really good to see this highlighted on a channel that is dedicated to climate change. Changing the way we do town planning and development is a central component of how we must tackle the climate and ecological emergency. Yet so much of the narrative is focussed on clean energy and other technofixes, which are of course important in their own right. However, rather than being the dominant narrative, clean energy solutions should be in place to fill in the gaps after we have got land-use planning right.  There are a number of parallels with where I live in Australia. Too much development beyond the urban fringe continues to be dedicated to large detached housing and entrenched car dependency. However, we can also make the argument that we shouldn't for the most part, be developing on the urban fringe at all.   Rezoning existing suburbs in Australia is also problematic because it increases land prices, helps gentrify neighbourhoods and requires large amounts of carbon to demolish and rebuild. The way to get around this is to only allow densification for the purposes of constructing new public housing. That way we can also be more selective about which housing stock is replaced. This allows us to increase public housing, add more housing diversity and keep the best housing stock. Because fundamentally we have to work with what we have. The existing suburbs are less than ideal but we can retrofit them to work much better in a post growth world.   I would be interested to know how much empty housing there is in America that could be filled. I am sure, that like Australia, there is a lot. The state of town planning and development under the current system is a huge reflection of why we need to transition to some form of post growth society that approaches planning and development in a new way. It would focus on filling uninhabited housing and retrofitting our existing stock. New housing would be constructed primarily on brownfield sites and also to replace existing poor quality housing in the existing built form (the greyfields).   I am part of a group called Town Planning Rebellion for anyone who is interested. https://www.facebook.com/groups/459336597565689

Great video -- I subscribed! It went by in kind of a flash, but it looks like you went to Columbia. So did I (CC77). On the topic of the video, though, I have an anecdote. I'm from NYC's Upper West Side, so I didn't even learn to drive until I was 40. (Terrifying.) Now I live in Los Angeles in... a single family home. We're three short blocks to groceries, drug stores, etc., so perhaps not technically a "suburb" (the Mar Vista neighborhood).   Here's the anecdote -- my stepson moved in with his girlfriend and they were looking for housing. They found a very small apartment in a (to my eye) ritzy high-rise apartment building on Wilshire Blvd. Very nice, but problem noisy neighbors. They moved to an incredibly cute old apartment, from the 1940s, in West Hollywood. Owned by a family and mostly the family lived in the units. I loved it. They had a neighbor (in an adjacent building) who screamed uncontrollably all day (mental health problem). And they started getting sick... turned out, CO2. They moved out to a nice apartment in Redondo Beach, next to his wife's parents. Lovely! Except for the neighbors upstairs who moved their furniture around ALL DAY and often into the night. Also the upstairs couple crowded a bunch of potted plants precariously on their balcony and... yes... one fell onto my stepson's patio. Could have killed someone.   FINALLY they found a place to live that is in a nice neighborhood, where they don't have neighbors through the wall bothering them all day. It's a single family home. They're still renting, but they probably couldn't get a mortgage anyway.   They're not unaware of climate issues, but their prior arrangements were intolerable. Landlords simply don't have the incentive to maintain apartments or keep peace between neighbors. Builders don't have incentive to soundproof or build quality into the structure. While I loved this video and to hear your perspectives on the issue, I'd like to also say a few problems I've encountered with your video:  1- Most of the problems that more extensive forms of housing create can be solved without the need to resort to people living in flats. Examples:  a) Energy efficiency is easily solved by insulating properly and by using more ecological alternatives to heating such as geothermal heat pump.  b) Having businesses within non-car distance can be solved by using more public transportation, bike lanes and pedestrian-only streets.  c) Taking up more space is true, but that's not necessarily negative. Focus on the real evils: lawns and excessive roads. Houses can be covered in solar panels, and loans could be turned into sustainable food forests that reduce dependency on food that has to be transported.   2) You give the example of Japan with "affordable" housing. I don't know if that's particularly true for Japan, but if it is, then it makes it the exception to the rule, so it's a bit pointless to use as an example. Go to any European country and compare the price per square meter of big cities with that of smaller towns. Housing is unaffordable in basically all big cities of Europe. Land that is allowed to be built on is released on patches big enough that only big companies can afford the investment. Housing prices are artificially high and huge money goes to already rich investors, furthering inequality  3) There is already a problem in many European countries with extreme de-ruralization. Rural areas are forgotten in favor of big towns. Companies establish themselves in big cities because of better infrastructure in a sort of feedback loop, making the infrastructure ever shrinking in rural areas and making life in the countryside harder and harder, especially if we talk about the possibility of finding or creating a job position for people with high-level education. In many croplands in Europe there are currently crops rotting from a lack of workers willing to pick them up for the comparably low wages that farmers can afford to pay them.   The solution in my opinion doesn't mean eliminating extensive forms of housing. Of course, maybe in the US there is a higher demand of intensive housing forms than there is availability, and as you said, let's make it so that people can live wherever they want. However, many of the existing problems with suburban sprawl can be solved by thinking and spending the correct amount of money in the correct type of infrastructure.

I've been thinking for a while now that housing in suburbia needs to be designed like Disneyland. The idea would be to build houses that look like they are single-family detached houses while using landscaping to hide the fact that they really aren't as Disneyland does so effectively. The houses would be arranged in such a way as to minimize the amount of road by clustering houses, underground passages if needed and shared or clustered garages. In turn green space would be maximized and paths would be built so that the walking/cycling routes are through the neighborhood while the driving routes keep to the outside, kind of like Amsterdam does. Mixed in between the clusters would be basic shops like groceries and such but not too many as ideally they would only serve the surrounding area and should not be a big magnet for outsiders.

Let your kids spend the after school hours in there, and you don't have to worry about the kind of person who likes isolated suburban houses because you can sneak victims into them without anybody seeing. Might be a good idea to  have a teenage district, too (to protect everyone else from the teenagers).  You could seriously have districts like that, if instead of having many sizes of dwellings (which are just relics of past constraints on development) you had just the "perfect layout".  And for someone who likes certain things about suburbia, "perfect" would be like suburbia rearranged. (I'm thinking mainly of gardens and garages - both for rock bands, and for dads that like to make furniture there's no more room for in the house).  The rearrangement is pretty simple in principle. "Make it dense". And the densest/ smallest footprint way to do that is with "apartment blocks". But then we come to the things that suck about apartments, so the only necessary aspect of these to carry over into the future is their small footprint.  One of the things that suck about apartments is that when the people upstairs start jumping on their bed, the noise comes through your roof. And a similar problem is that whenever you start your pogo routine the people below bang on the roof for you to stop it. Shared walls and horizontal surfaces are nice for saving materials, but they can be noisy.  So separate all units on all sides? I've read somewhere that a cavity wall has a soundproofing effect. So it would seem to make sense to separate units laterally with cavity walls - and translucent ones, too - to let in light. Then there's the top of your unit/ bottom of the neighbours to worry about. Make it into open air space (with some kind of insulation option for cold days). To keep it that way, you have to make it impossible to turn it into an extension. I'd go for lots of "structure" - beams, trusses, arches, ogives, tracery, buttresses, columns, etc. Try to fix it so that the integrity of the floor upstairs depends on all those structural elements that you have to duck under when moving around more than necessary on your "roof-balcony". Make the floor slab thinner, and support it in many more places.  Might be a bit much requiring an open space on top. Really all I want is to have an adequate place for your dog to go out into the breeze to have a snooze (instead of having a snooze on your couch). It's essential for people to be able to still keep dogs.  The other thing I'd do different to usual apartments is to "make up for the loss of the street" (for e.g. deliveries). So have a delivery passage as well as the usual door access passage. Reserve it for robotic package deliveries, meal deliveries, washing deliveries, and emergency services. (You'd also put all your wiring and piping in there, nice and exposed so it's easy to see if it's leaking or sparking.)  Gardens. Use the whole suburb's worth of space you have after piling up the houses in the center. (Don't go squeezing more of these buildings in. That would make it a hell. You want single buildings standing in glorious isolation among pastures that run right up to their very feet.  This would need to be something to try on new developments, rather than retrofit (although there are plenty of parking lots you could fit such a development into.
I got here from NJB, and I wanted to point out a bit in his video about empty property in the city being used for surface parking instead of housing, and I really, REALLY think that's a far bigger issue than suburban zoning. It's the thing that drives the sprawl that we're all complaining about; younger people increasingly want density, they want walkability, they want urban living. The other thing that doesn't get explored in depth is financing of lower income development. Banks just don't want to do it.
A bag of milk is actually more economical:  - single material packaging, easier to recycle (cartons are many layers of different materials and thus more difficult to recycle) - thinner packaging = less packaging (it takes a lot more material to make rigid jugs)
Bags of milk are sealed, the pics you showed... not sure where that's from. But fun fact: they are actually environmentally better other forms (even better than "recyclable" jugs). 4L come in 3 (sealed) bags and therefore are 1) easier to store than a 4L jug and 2) stay fresh longer cause you're only opening 1/3 at a time. People think it's "weird", but there are literally better in every way. And the "inconvenience" is overstated. Once you realize all you need is scissors/knife/bag opener to open them and it literally takes 3 seconds to cut them.

Why do we have a bag of milk in Canada?  Because one of our milk companies discovered that, to comply with Canadian laws and convert their milk cartons from imperial measurements to metric back in the 70s, it was easier to convert their plastic wrap machines to store the milk, so that it would save money. I went to two planning meetings for urban planning classes I took at university in my early 20s.  In one, a lady was complaining about a developer flooding her yard when he was doing site work for townhouses he was seeking approval for - which she had not brought up to him previously or told the board about previously.  The other one had an older guy upset that they were making his neighborhood a historic district - it was full of old mixed-use and industrial buildings, many of which sit empty and would benefit from the incentives for them to be rehabilitated and adaptively reused as a mix of offices, retail and housing.  I also went to one for my job where I was the youngest person in the room and the planning board was *horrified* that we were proposing a two-story garage with a studio featuring large windows above it on an alley that was historically home to several multi-story buildings, but it was legal under zoning and only required minor variances, so it was approved.  But they were upset about how many windows and privacy.  Well, if you want privacy, maybe you shouldn't live in a neighborhood like that one where the houses are literally less than 5 feet apart and already have many windows looking at neighboring houses and yards. Bagged milk is an *excellent* solution for milk, you just need to think for 2 seconds about how to use it.  --Everyone who buys bagged milk that I talk to has a jug that holds the open bag such that it can be conveniently poured from.  Or you can just put it in a pitcher of milk that you keep in your fridge. --Bagged milk has an absolute minimum of packaging necessary to contain it.  A thin membrane that provides containment of the product.  I've yet to see milk sold in the kind of heavy duty plastic that's actually worth recycling and thus doesn't wind up in the landfill or incinerator one way or another.  Or would you rather we use glass bottles?  Sure they're reusable, but they get lost and glass has a very high energy cost to make. --What milk packaging have you seen that's stackable?  Everything I've seen comes to a point, or pretty close to it, which makes stacking difficult at best. --You actually can stack bagged milk - the bags that we used to have around here were, when full, about the size and shape of an average brick , with a little rounding on the edges.  Since there's no sharp corners to pierce the bag, you can stack the bags several bags deep before you start building up enough crushing power to burst the bottom one. --Since the packaging is so small, you're not spending anywhere near as much on the cost of the packaging.  Bag milk is usually a good 10 cents or more cheaper than any of the alternatives.  Bagged milk is excellent: convenient, economical, and the closest thing we have to an environmentally friendly packaging that I've seen applied to milk, simply by virtue of minimalism.

Bags of milk are *_NOT_* the single family housing of milk storage.  Bags of milk use less material to contain the milk, which means less waste generated for landfills. This is because paper cartons are nearly unrecyclable in most recycling facilities.  To prevent spillage, you put the milk bag in a pitcher and clip the opening shut. Meaning, you have a reusable milk container combined with a negligible disposable plastic lining.  Bags of milk are the mid-rises of the dairy world.

These are some of the issues I see with this solution in America  1. Price per sq ft. is typically to high where owning a single family detached home makes more sense. I can buy a house in the bay area for the same price as I can rent an apartment, why would I ever rent when it makes more sense to own. Unless you figure a way to make it affordable and keep it that way, capitalism will win keeping cost high. Potential solution would be to cap the cost of rent 45% below the median price mortgage for a home in that area. Meaning, if I'm renting a 3bed 2bath apartment and the median price to own is $4000 a month, then rent cannot be higher than $1800. Capitalism will win and this is not feasible for them to do. 2. Limited parking discouraging anyone to ever visit you. I'd like to have friends and family visit me at my place. Open spots are typically occupied by other B-Hole neighbors with 12 cars. If parking goes unassigned, then you will be lucky to find a secure spot at all. 3. Parking that is available, is so compact, anyone with a sedan or bigger vehicle will most certainly get dings and dents. They make the spots so tiny that you can barely get in and out of your vehicle without swinging the door into someone else. 4. Sound proofing is almost non-existent. Meaning you get kids running around the hallways screaming and you can hear it through your door. Find a way in which I can have a loud stereo in my house and my neighbor next-door can't hear it what so ever. 5. Nearly all HOA's or Apartments almost never maintain the property or enforce any code violations. Any vegetation that is planted is an after thought. They plan things in hot climates that shouldn't be there that end up dieing. Those dead plants are never replaced. Noisey neighbors, kids that go around vandalizing private property, neighbors who don't pick up after their pets, cars that are parked and never moved. If they decide to do anything, it's a fine, but nothing is done with repeat offenders. HOA's or Property Mangement are never held accountable for NOT doing what they should be doing. 6. Moving into a building that is on a 4+ story apartment/condo is tiring and can be costly if you pay someone to move you  7. Driving around these area's is also a pain. Typically 1 or 2 lanes in each direction, making it impossible for me to leave the area. People who live there, typically work away from there, creating congestion. A solution to this would have city/state governments provide incentives to stay at home and work. 8. You are typically limited 1 ISP provider, meaning that you cannot downgrade to another provider to save money if needed, or if you are not happy with the provider you have you cannot leave. And again, if capitalism has it's way, you can be charged whatever they'd like because you need it and only have 1 option. 9. I have 2 big dogs, almost all of these spots do not allow animal's over a certain weight and/or breed. I wouldn't be allowed to move into these spots with this restriction. Sorry, but they are family and I'm not going to get rid of them. there are opinions about big dogs in small spaces, but when you are an active person who works from home, this isn't an issue. You regularly give them exercise. If it's about damage, I've seen cats do some shady stuff. If it's about noise, any sized/breed of dog, can bark all day if they are not trained. Basically, it's easier to deal with the animal then the owner of that animal. 10. Security is also another after-thought. I don't care if you live in a well established area or not, nothing is done about protecting private property. Camera's installed typically never work or allow you to have access to footage. If you park your car, you are gambling that it will be there or not broken into. I expect that whatever security that is put into place to protect my stuff at all times of the day. You get lazy security guards who never patrol, that claim no responsibility for property damage, why have them there anyway.     I am not really against the idea of high density or mixed use land. However, the way it's developed/maintained is done poorly. It's done in a manner that benefits only the developer because they make the most off of this. May of the issues I presented can be had with single family homes too, but these mostly happen in HDR area's.

Canadian here. The bags of milk are used in conjunction with a re-useable milk jug that holds the bag upright while its in the fridge. The upper corner is cut allowing the milk to be easily poured with the jug. Once a bag is empty you switch out for a new one, the bags come sealed so you can store them on their sides. This means less plastic is used than a big jug (cartons are probably still better for the environment) and it takes up less space.

Between this and the fact I can get anything delivered to my door, including groceries if I don't feel like doing them myself, and for nights out I can always get Uber (or other local equivalents), I really don't see myself getting another car any time soon. The expense of owning and maintaining a car just doesn't seem worth it anymore.  Plus working from home has really taken off in my industry and I doubt the days of 5 day mandatory office attendance will ever come back. That's probably a topic onto itself. There are plenty of domains where working from home has proven to be not only feasible, but even beneficial. People don't waste time commuting every day, companies can afford to have smaller offices, this in turn means fewer emissions associated with getting people to and from work or with heating and electricity for oversized office spaces.  The only downside for me is that, unfortunately, unlike in other places in Europe it's not very cycling friendly around here. If that were to change, I wouldn't even need the bus to travel into the city.

Most city councils have a website that people only ever use to pay their bills. Fun fact: a lot of these websites have open public engagement sections to get feedback on upcoming projects and changes they want to implement. Town planners generally aren't dumb and recognise the need to loosen housing regulation and the only thing stopping them is backlash from nimbys, who are generally the only group of people that get involved with council engagement. Look around the website for your city. If they list their projects and have a means to give feedback, find something that will make your city a better place and lend a positive voice. It helps more than you might expect! Lack of community support is usually the only thing holding a city back from making some major improvements.

I walked from our 5th story apartment, three blocks to the local grocers for a liter bag of milk on the regular as a 5year old kinder in Frankfurt, Germany. It's a thing. Bags stack. They use fewer resources and take up less space. Stores can fill them from bulk containers on site. Some will even fill your own reusable container. At home you pour the milk into your own pitcher and then recycle the bag. Waxed milk cartons weren't accepted by curbside recycling until like a couple years ago. Cardboard milk boxes are the R1 zoning of dairy containers.

Zoning Meeting Inspiration Story:  I went to a city council meeting in my city and they were discussing a new development. The developer wanted to build something like a 60 unit apartment building. He provided parking for 1.32 parking spaces per bedroom, but the zoning required 1.5. The developer had done a study at another nearby complex he owned showing that the demand in the area was actually 1.12 spots per bedroom and so 1.32 should be plenty. The City Council was still all worried about the parking and then when public comment came up, I and one other dude commented and explained that we thought the parking shouldn't be an issue. We were in the target demographic and both of us had one car per household and assured the council that it wouldn't be an issue. After that the council decided that they would write up some development agreements stating that the developer would be responsible for restricting its residence from bringing too many cars which would make the development acceptable to build. It felt like such a win. Going to council meetings can totally make difference.

Shopping malls are actually good if they are spread up (many floors) not only sideways, and if they are in (or close to) areas that are walkable and with lots of public transportation. Shopping malls are a great way to have many of your shopping needs in a single (walkable) place when they are built like this. Here in my country most shopping malls have at least 3 floors and are *always* in the "city centers", which are places that have a lot of public transportation to other areas of the city and are *very* walkable. Shopping malls are great when you are in a hurry and need to find everything you need in a single place, or when you need to compare prices of items. Will re-state my tl;dr comment from NotJustBikes here:  Consider the pathology (the science and study of the origin, nature, and course of a phenomenon):  The exiled Europeans that conquered the Americas came from a culture of "Landed Aristocracy/Nobility": The category of Nobility in various countries over history, for which landownership was part of their noble privileges. In this case, The British nobility that consisted of members of the immediate families of peers who bear courtesy titles or honorifics.  Peerage rankings such as Duke, Marquess, Earl, Viscount, and Baron - they where the Only Humans that Could OWN LAND. Furthermore, not just the land, but everything on the land, including the other humans inhabiting it.  So now lets think how cultures are formed.  The top tier in the English Culture was the Landed Aristocracy/Nobility.  Humans want to be respected and have dignity.  Landed Aristocracy/Nobility were dignified & respected - the peasants/surfs who toiled the lands had none.  Religion then comes into play to provide an "divine" explanation to the uneducated and superstitious masses of peasants/surfs - which promised dignity and wealth in the afterworld...if one accepts their Caste laborer status and they worked hard for their overlords.  These same religious outcast were the ones to conquer the Americas...and they brought their cultural worship of landed nobility with them - Including a far more brutal and barbaric method of "owning" the people who worked the land.  Land ownership was the ultimate status symbol (Like being a "on-paper" Billionaire is today).  Once the word got out that  if one Worked Hard, - America was a vast land of riches and Land Ownership, more Europeans followed.  This is where the twin concepts of Rugged Individualism and Manifest Destiny (the idea that the United States is destined‚Äîby God, its advocates believed‚Äîto expand its dominion and spread the now mutated ideology  across the entire North American continent) originates.  Each Man desired his own plot of land.  To be the King in his own Home...just like European Landed Aristocracy/Nobility.  One could be "Re-Caste" into a higher social structure, and - just like Landed Aristocracy/Nobility - have these privilege's automatically be passed on to their descendants at the Caste level, not the bloodline level.    Thus, the culture has evolved over the generations, to perceive owning a plot of land as the apex of Dignity and Respect.  Human behavior is dictated by Culture, Tribe, Tradition, and Custom.  Americans still perceive Single Family Home ownership as the single most important Social statement  - and therefore our land-use structure reflects this: everyone can have their own plot of land and be "landed." Formalized peasant ownership (slavery) is gone, but the vestiges of Landed Aristocracy/Nobility still remain in that Suburbs are enclosed circles of perceived "Nobility" who control, but are away from the peasants/surf Caste who toil the land (so to speak).  So nothing can ever change.  It's a cultural and Human Behavior thing.
